text: <@U2WAP0R6J> Hi. The only idea I have now is to remove old images, remove `vendor` directory from you chaincode directory and to start from the scratch. I believe that is what I have done on my machine.
thanks, can I ask you what you did exactly?
I do `govendor init` and `govendor fetch <http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric|github.com/hyperledger/fabric>`
err `govendor fetch <http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric@v.0.6.0|github.com/hyperledger/fabric@v.0.6.0>`
then i try to deploy and i get an error that it doesnt have the shim
it should be `govendor fetch <http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric@v0.6|github.com/hyperledger/fabric@v0.6>`
so i `govendor fetch <http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/chaincode/shim@v0.6.0|github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/chaincode/shim@v0.6.0>`

and I remember that it was unable to find `fabric/peer/core.yaml`. If you have such error you probably need to make `govendor fetch <http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer@v0.6|github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer@v0.6>`
i dont have that error
after you make `govendor` be sure your vendor directory contains `hyperledger/fabric` files
like all the files?
on that govendor fetch of fabric i only have `LICENSE  Makefile  mkdocs.yml  README.md  settings.gradle  TravisCI_Readme.md`
Looks like that is not enough
makes sense, was wondering why the shim wasnt in there

```LICENSE
consensus
core
events
flogging
membersrvc
metadata
peer
protos```
this is what I have
really weird that the command is not pulling the whole thing for me - what am i missing?
ok so `govendor fetch <http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer@v0.6|github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer@v0.6>` does fetch the shim package
but still getting the error :disappointed:
are you sure the images you pulled also have the same version?
i've got `hyperledger/fabric-peer         x86_64-0.6.0-preview`
same version for membersrvc image
what have you done for the `hyperledger/fabric-baseimage`?
i had to pull that also, i pulled `hyperledger/fabric-baseimage    x86_64-0.2.0 `
and then tagged it `latest` since it looks for that
nothing. I pulled `hyperledger/fabric-peer` and just tagged it to `hyperledger/fabric-baseimage`

<@U2X9KDDL7|vdods> has joined the channel
I'd like to get some clarification on how the key-columns in chaincode tables work.  They're clearly used to identify rows in a given table.  Can a given table have more than one key-column?

The comments in core/chaincode/shim/interfaces.go:GetRows suggest there can be more than one key -- but then what does GetRow do?  Does it have to have all keys specified such that the row is uniquely identified?
<@U2X9KDDL7> : Use CreateTable to create the table.  Then you use GetRow to query for all keys in the table.  GetRows allows you to query by a subset of keys.
So if you CreateTable and specify column A and B as keys, you can use GetRow to query for the row that matches A and B.  Or you could use GetRows to return all the rows with values that match A.
<@U2LV4CC6B> Thanks!
<@U2BF87970|sumitks> has joined the channel

Hey All, regarding how tables work in Hyperledger can anyone explain to me _why_ they are are set up like this - I mean what advantage is there to not allowing the user to specify an arbitrary key and search on it and forcing them to do `GetRows()` with a linear combination of them?

<@U2DHRR4TE>
 Personally, the table interfaces are hard to use and not efficient. It's a better way directly to use the GetState() and PutState(). 
I think GetRows() is used for range query (just set the parameter 'key' to nil).  For specifying an arbitrary key, use the GetRow(). Hope will help you.
